reviewText: Great picture quality and Charley Chase was one of the most talented director/comedian/writer you will ever find, no mater what generation you search.  Now if we can convince Sony that Andy Clyde and their other shorts also have a market.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Charley actually rings some of his silent comedy antics to these Columbia Comedies.Some fans have felt that some of Charlie's sound Hal Roach films lost some of the slapstick magic that his silent films had.But this magic reappears in his Columbia Comedies.  Columbia was the refuge for classic short subject comics in the 1930's & 1940's.I even caught a nod to Laurel & Hardy as Charlie outwitted a villain and crosses the trolly tracks. He does an Oliver Hardy smirk and we hear a suggestion of the Cuckoo song on the soundtrack.One suggestion I would make when watching these gems, don't watch the first two in a row.  Their subject matter is too similar to enjoy back-to-back.  These are presented chronologically and that is why they appear together.
summary: Charley is always GREAT! And he shines at Columbia Studios.
Title: N/A

reviewText: One shouldn't feel any regrets that comedy genius Charley Chase never starred in a feature film. For the short subject seemed to be the perfect length to present his style of comedy. "For He's a Jolly Good Fellow" also seemed to be the appropriate theme song for Chase, because although he worked diligently on his comedies (sometimes as writer, producer and/or director), Chase never took himself too seriously, making himself more personable to audiences in front of the camera. He was a great mechanic of film comedy, really knowing his stuff, with impeccable timing. He would take a situation and elevate it to dizzying comic heights, milking a story for all it was worth.Chase's tenure at Columbia bore delicious fruit, for his style meshed well with the wild slapstick goings on there (witness the huge success of The Three Stooges). Again with Volume 2, all the shorts are pure gems.There's no extras, although a featurette on Chase's career at Columbia would have been a nice treat. Chase's untimely death might have brought his career to a halt. But let's be thankful for all the great laughs Mr. Chase left behind!
summary: The wonderful Charley Chase's last hurrahs at Columbia

reviewText: Vintage-comedy fans have been awaiting the release of these long-unseen short subjects for years. Sony obliged with a sampling on Volume One; Volume Two offers the balance. Here are 12 more examples of what made Charley Chase such an appealing and durable comedy star.Chase had been working on both sides of the camera since his Mack Sennett days, beginning in 1914. By the mid-1930s he was firmly established as a short-subject star (alongside Laurel & Hardy and Our Gang) at the Hal Roach Studios. Chase moved to Columbia in 1937, where the emphasis was on physical humor and farcical situations. Unlike fellow silent-comedy vets Buster Keaton and Harry Langdon -- whose tenures at Columbia were sometimes littered with blunt, Three Stooges-like scripts and direction -- Charley Chase remained the master of his situation and came up with some choice comedy.Chase's forte was the comedy of embarrassment, in a situation-comedy format. His screen character was constantly getting the wrong end of the stick (mistaking a lunatic for a physician; being mistaken for a skirt-chasing mobster; getting in trouble when his girl sees his picture on the front page, etc.). The Columbias are loaded with these zany premises, and Chase plays them to the hilt.The 12 shorts in this collection are:THE GRAND HOOTER (1937) Good-time Charley's staunch dedication to his Hoot Owls lodge gets him in hot water. Two points of interest: Nena Quartaro from his Hal Roach comedies is in this, and he sings.FROM BAD TO WORSE (1937) Perhaps the most obscure of his Columbias. His honeymoon goes from bad to worse when another woman shows up, followed by her jealous husband.THE WRONG MISS WRIGHT (1937) Borrowing a plotline from one of his silents, Chase enjoys a shipboard romance, which is doomed by a prearranged marriage to someone else.CALLING ALL DOCTORS (1937) Hopeless hypochondriac Charley is treated by an escaped lunatic. His reactions to the nut (vaudeville's John T. Murray) are very funny.THE BIG SQUIRT (1937) Drugstore employee Charley, zealously following true-crime stories, fails to recognize a public enemy at his soda fountain. Special treat: he sings, disguised as a one-man band.TIME OUT FOR TROUBLE (1938) When his girlfriend dumps him, Charley decides to end it all by hiring a hit man (Columbia stalwart villain Dick Curtis), providing Chase doesn't know when the blow will fall!MANY SAPPY RETURNS (1938) Cab driver Charley, in love with the big boss's daughter, hopes to impress her father. Unfortunately he runs into a lunatic (Murray again) who claims to be the very man.THE NIGHTSHIRT BANDIT (1938) Fast-paced mayhem on campus, as college professor Chase tries to catch the thief who's being raiding the women's dormitory. This is the only Chase comedy directed by Stoogemeister Jules White, so the action is more frenzied than usual. White later remade this one (twice) with former Mack Sennett star Andy Clyde.PIE A LA MAID (1938) Charley keeps blundering into the paths of the same girl (Ann Doran) and the same grouchy man (Lionel Belmore). This one actually has a musical score (played on an organ, adding a silent-comedy touch).THE SAP TAKES A WRAP (1939) Charley gets mixed up with a trio of showgirls, and a mink coat that keeps changing hands. Watch for Joan Blondell's sister, Gloria, as the ingenue.TEACHER'S PEST (1939) Charley accepts a teaching job -- little realizing it's in a one-room schoolhouse in hostile hillbilly country.HIS BRIDAL FRIGHT (1940) Charley, wanting to impress his girl's philatelist father, needs postage stamps from exotic places. He mails letters to these locations but gets more than stamps in return -- all the girls who received the letters show up at once! Iris Meredith, a wonderful ingenue in Columbia's westerns and serials, makes her only featured appearance for the two-reel-comedy unit.Chase never received directorial credit on any of his Columbia comedies (although he was credited as producer and/or writer). Most of the shorts in this set were directed by Mack Sennett veteran Del Lord. Many of Lord's two-reelers stop abruptly when the 17 minutes are up, but the situations are strong enough to keep you amused during those 17 minutes. If you know your Three Stooges shorts, you'll enjoy seeing the same familiar faces in the supporting casts (Bud Jamison, Vernon Dent, Richard Fiske, John Tyrrell, etc.) and you may recognize some of the same sets and locations!Archivist Grover Crisp did a great job with the restorations from 35mm vault materials. The 12 shorts have been compiled on a single disc, but they still look and sound terrific because the 17-minute shorts total about three-and-a-half hours, which is par for today's triple-feature DVD releases. Grab this set while you can.
summary: The other 12 Chase Columbias. The prints are knockouts!
